questions.question: The first step in troubleshooting an underperforming PV system is:

options.text: Gather information: error codes, production history, recent changes

questions.explanation: Systematic troubleshooting starts with information gathering: check inverter error codes, review production history in monitoring, ask about recent events (weather, maintenance, outages), and compare current vs. expected performance.

questions.question: Before troubleshooting DC PV circuits, what safety precautions are required?

options.text: PPE, open disconnects, verify zero energy or use LOTO procedures

questions.explanation: DC circuits are energized in daylight. Wear appropriate PPE (insulated gloves, safety glasses), open all accessible disconnects, verify zero voltage with rated meter, or implement LOTO if work on energized circuits is unavoidable. Cover modules with opaque material.

questions.question: An inverter displays 'Ground Fault' error. The first troubleshooting step is:

options.text: Check for damaged wiring insulation, wet connections, or module damage

questions.explanation: Ground faults indicate unintended current path to ground. Inspect for damaged wire insulation (especially at roof penetrations, junction boxes), water intrusion, rodent damage, or module glass/junction box damage. Use megger to locate affected circuit.

questions.question: An 'Arc Fault' error typically indicates:

options.text: Loose connection, damaged conductor, or corroded terminal

questions.explanation: Arc faults result from high-resistance connections creating sparks. Causes include loose MC4 connectors, corroded terminals, damaged conductors, or poor crimps. Inspect all connections, look for heat damage or discoloration, re-torque terminals.

questions.question: Inverter shows 'Overvoltage' or 'DC Input High' error. The likely cause is:

options.text: Too few modules in the string
String voltage exceeds inverter maximum, often due to cold temperature

questions.explanation: Cold temperatures increase Voc above STC ratings. If string design didn't account for lowest expected temperature per NEC 690.7(A), voltage can exceed inverter limits. May require removing a module from affected strings or inverter replacement.

questions.question: Inverter displays 'Grid Fault' or 'Utility Voltage Error'. This indicates:

options.text: Grid voltage or frequency outside acceptable range

questions.explanation: Grid fault errors indicate utility voltage or frequency outside inverter's operating window (typically ±10% voltage, 59.3-60.5 Hz). Check with voltmeter at service entrance. May be utility issue, loose service connection, or undersized conductors causing voltage rise.

questions.question: Inverter shows 'Isolation Fault' or 'ISO Error'. This typically means:

options.text: The inverter is isolated from the grid
DC circuit insulation resistance to ground is too low

questions.explanation: Isolation faults indicate low insulation resistance between DC conductors and ground. Caused by moisture, damaged insulation, or manufacturing defects. Use megger to test each string. May be intermittent with morning dew or rain.

questions.question: One string has significantly lower Voc than parallel strings with the same module count. This suggests:

options.text: One or more modules have bypass diodes conducting or open circuits

questions.explanation: Low string Voc indicates module-level voltage loss. Each conducting bypass diode drops ~0.5V but bypasses ~1/3 module voltage (15-20V). Count the voltage 'steps' missing to estimate affected modules. Check for severe shading, damaged cells, or poor connections.

questions.question: One string has significantly lower Isc than parallel strings. Possible causes include:

options.text: Shading, soiling, module damage, or high-resistance connection

questions.explanation: Low Isc indicates current limitation. In series strings, the lowest-current module limits the entire string. Check for shading, soiling, cracked cells, damaged bypass diodes, or high-resistance connections that limit current flow.

questions.question: String Voc measures zero. The most likely cause is:

options.text: Open circuit (disconnected cable, broken conductor, or blown fuse)

questions.explanation: Zero Voc indicates complete open circuit—no current path. Check for disconnected MC4 connectors, broken conductors (especially at junction boxes or flexing points), or blown string fuses. Trace the circuit from module to inverter.

questions.question: When measuring string Voc, the proper procedure is:

options.text: Disconnect string from inverter/combiner and measure with calibrated DC voltmeter

questions.explanation: Disconnect the string from the inverter or combiner. Use a DC voltmeter rated for the expected voltage. Measure across positive and negative string conductors. Compare to calculated Voc (modules × Voc × temperature correction).

questions.question: When measuring string Isc, special precautions are needed because:

options.text: High current can damage the meter if not properly rated and connected

questions.explanation: String Isc can exceed 10A. Use a DC clamp meter rated for the expected current, or a shunt with voltmeter. Never measure high current with a standard meter in voltage mode. Clamp around ONE conductor only (both cancels the reading).

questions.question: Insulation resistance testing (megger test) should show:

options.text: Greater than 1 MΩ between conductors and ground

questions.explanation: Per IEC 62446, insulation resistance should exceed 1 MΩ at test voltage (typically 500V or 1000V DC). Low readings indicate insulation breakdown. Test positive-to-ground and negative-to-ground separately to identify the affected conductor.

questions.question: A megger test shows low insulation resistance only when testing the positive conductor. This indicates:

options.text: Insulation fault on the positive conductor path

questions.explanation: Low resistance on only one polarity narrows the fault to that conductor's path. Systematically isolate sections (disconnect at junction boxes, combiners) and retest to locate the specific segment with the fault.

questions.question: An IV curve tracer measures:

options.text: Current and voltage at many points from Isc to Voc

questions.explanation: IV curve tracers sweep from short-circuit (Isc) to open-circuit (Voc), recording I-V pairs throughout. The resulting curve shape reveals module/string health. Compare to expected curve to identify shading, soiling, mismatch, or resistance issues.

questions.question: A 'stepped' or 'staircased' IV curve indicates:

options.text: Partial shading causing bypass diodes to conduct at different voltages

questions.explanation: Steps in the IV curve appear when bypass diodes conduct due to shaded or damaged cells. Each step represents a bypassed cell group. The number and location of steps help identify affected modules and severity of shading.

questions.question: An IV curve with reduced fill factor (more 'rounded' knee) suggests:

options.text: Increased series resistance from poor connections or cell degradation

questions.explanation: Reduced fill factor (FF) indicates resistive losses. Causes include corroded connections, high-resistance solder joints in cells, or degraded cells. The curve 'sags' away from the ideal rectangular shape, reducing power at MPP.

questions.question: An IV curve showing normal Voc but reduced Isc (curve shifted down) indicates:

options.text: Uniform irradiance reduction from soiling or low sun

questions.explanation: Current scales with irradiance while voltage is relatively stable. A downward shift with maintained Voc indicates uniform light reduction—soiling, haze, clouds, or low sun angle. Clean modules and retest to compare.

questions.question: Thermal imaging of a PV array is used to detect:

options.text: Hot spots, defective cells, and poor connections

questions.explanation: Thermal cameras reveal temperature differences. Hot cells indicate damage, reverse-biased operation, or poor bypass diodes. Hot connections indicate high resistance. Conduct thermal scans at ≥50% irradiance for best results.

questions.question: A hot spot on a single cell in a thermal image typically indicates:

options.text: Damaged cell, shading, or soiling causing reverse-bias heating

questions.explanation: Hot cells are typically shaded, cracked, or have damaged contacts. When reverse-biased by the series string, they dissipate power as heat. Sustained hot spots can damage encapsulants and pose fire risk. The affected module may need replacement.

questions.question: One entire module appears hotter than adjacent modules in a thermal scan. This could indicate:

options.text: Faulty bypass diode or high-resistance connection

questions.explanation: A uniformly hotter module may have a faulty junction box, high-resistance connection, or failed bypass diode. The entire module is working harder to overcome the limitation, generating more heat. Check connections and test the module.

questions.question: Production data shows gradual decline over months, not related to seasonal changes. Likely causes include:

options.text: Soiling accumulation, vegetation growth, or module degradation

questions.explanation: Gradual production decline suggests progressive issues: soiling buildup, tree/vegetation growth causing new shading, or normal module degradation (~0.5%/year). Cleaning, trimming, and performance testing can identify and address the cause.

questions.question: Production suddenly drops 25% on a specific date. First troubleshooting step:

options.text: Check for new shading, failed equipment, or specific string offline

questions.explanation: Sudden production drops suggest discrete failures: string offline (fuse, connector, inverter MPPT), new shading (construction, tree), or equipment failure. 25% drop on a 4-string system = 1 string likely offline. Check inverter data and site conditions.

questions.question: Morning production is normal but afternoon production is low. Possible cause:

options.text: Afternoon shading from tree, building, or object

questions.explanation: Time-specific production loss indicates shading at that time. Visit the site during the affected hours to observe shade patterns. New construction, tree growth, or seasonal sun angle changes can create shading that wasn't present at installation.

questions.question: System produces less in summer than expected despite higher irradiance. Likely cause:

options.text: High temperature reducing voltage and power

questions.explanation: High summer temperatures reduce module voltage (and power) significantly. A module at 65°C produces 10-15% less than at 25°C. This is normal temperature derating. Compare to PVWatts or similar models that account for temperature.

questions.question: A chimney casts a shadow on 2 modules for 2 hours daily. With string inverter and no MLPE, the impact is:

options.text: The entire string output is reduced during shading

questions.explanation: In series strings without MLPE, the shaded modules limit current for the entire string. Bypass diodes minimize losses but don't eliminate them. The whole string suffers reduced output during the shading period.

questions.question: After tree trimming, production increased 15%. This confirms:

options.text: Tree growth was causing significant shading losses

questions.explanation: Production increase after tree trimming directly confirms shading was reducing output. Trees can grow several feet per year. Ongoing vegetation management should be part of the maintenance plan for sites with nearby trees.

questions.question: After heavy dust storm, system production dropped 10%. The solution is:

options.text: Clean the modules with appropriate methods

questions.explanation: Dust and debris accumulation reduces light reaching cells. Clean modules with water (deionized if possible) and soft brush/squeegee. Avoid scratching glass. In dry climates, regular cleaning schedules improve production. Some areas lose 5%+ to soiling.

questions.question: Bird droppings on a single module cause what type of production impact?

options.text: Potential hot spot on affected cells and reduced string output

questions.explanation: Bird droppings create opaque shading on individual cells, potentially causing hot spots from reverse-biasing. In series strings, the shaded cells limit current for the entire string. Clean affected modules promptly to prevent damage and restore output.

questions.question: An MC4 connector feels warm/hot during system operation. This indicates:
questions.explanation: Hot connectors indicate high resistance (I²R heating) from poor crimps, corrosion, moisture, or mismatched connector brands. This is a fire hazard. De-energize and replace affected connectors immediately. Check for heat damage to insulation.

questions.question: Intermittent system faults that clear after connector manipulation suggest:

options.text: Loose connection or damaged connector requiring replacement

questions.explanation: Intermittent faults from connector manipulation indicate a marginal connection that makes/breaks with movement. Don't leave it—replace the connector. Wind, thermal cycling, or vibration will cause future failures. Inspect for corrosion or damage.

questions.question: Corroded terminals on a combiner bus bar should be:

options.text: Cleaned with appropriate methods or replaced if damaged

questions.explanation: Corrosion creates high resistance and intermittent connections. Clean with appropriate contact cleaner and wire brush if surface corrosion only. Replace terminals if significantly pitted or damaged. Apply anti-corrosion compound per manufacturer specs.

questions.question: Brown or yellow discoloration on a module surface indicates:
questions.explanation: Encapsulant (EVA) browning/yellowing results from UV exposure and heat, especially in older or poor-quality modules. This reduces light reaching cells and indicates degradation. Affected modules typically underperform and may warrant warranty claim.

questions.question: Snail trails (dark lines following cell edges) on a module indicate:

options.text: Micro-cracks that allow moisture and silver migration

questions.explanation: Snail trails are caused by moisture entering through micro-cracks in cells and reacting with silver from contacts. They indicate cell damage that may reduce output. Often result from handling damage or manufacturing defects. May be warrantable.

questions.question: Delamination (bubbles, separated layers) in a module is caused by:

options.text: Moisture ingress, manufacturing defect, or thermal cycling

questions.explanation: Delamination indicates encapsulant separation from cells or glass due to moisture, manufacturing issues, or thermal stress. It reduces output, allows further moisture ingress, and poses safety concerns. Replace affected modules; document for warranty claim.

questions.question: A cracked module glass should be:

options.text: Replaced—cracked glass compromises safety and performance

questions.explanation: Cracked glass allows moisture ingress leading to cell damage, ground faults, and potential shock hazards. Even if producing now, degradation will accelerate. Replace the module. Document for warranty claim. Never leave cracked glass in service.

questions.question: A module's junction box is melted or discolored. The appropriate action is:

options.text: Immediately de-energize, document, and replace the module

questions.explanation: Melted junction boxes indicate severe overheating from internal connection failure—a fire hazard. Immediately de-energize (cover the module), document with photos for warranty/insurance, and replace. Inspect adjacent modules and wiring for damage.

questions.question: Inverter won't start in the morning despite good sunlight. First check:

options.text: Verify DC disconnect is closed and string voltage exceeds start voltage

questions.explanation: Check the basics: DC disconnect on, AC disconnect on, no lockouts. Measure string voltage—must exceed inverter start voltage (typically 100-200V). Low voltage in morning (dew, low sun) is normal until sufficient irradiance. Check for error codes.

questions.question: Inverter display is blank and LEDs are off despite being connected. Check:

options.text: Both AC and DC supply—inverter needs one or both to power up

questions.explanation: Most inverters power control electronics from DC input and/or AC grid. Check both: verify DC voltage at inverter terminals, verify AC voltage from panel. Blown fuses, open disconnects, or tripped breakers could prevent power-up.

questions.question: Inverter internal fan runs constantly at high speed. This indicates:

options.text: Overheating—check ventilation, airflow, and ambient temperature

questions.explanation: Constant high-speed fan operation indicates the inverter is working hard to dissipate heat. Check for blocked vents, direct sunlight, poor ventilation, or high ambient temperature. Overheating causes derating and premature failure.

questions.question: Inverter shows 'AC Disconnect Open' or similar when the breaker is clearly closed. This could indicate:

options.text: Poor AC connection, wire fault, or voltage outside range

questions.explanation: The inverter senses AC presence through voltage measurement. If it doesn't detect proper AC despite breaker being on, check: AC voltage at inverter terminals, wire connections, neutral connection (if required), and tripped upstream breakers.

questions.question: One MPPT input on a dual-MPPT inverter shows much lower power than the other identical string. Check:

options.text: String voltage, current, shading, and connection integrity

questions.explanation: Compare voltages and currents between MPPT inputs. Lower voltage = possible shading, bypass diode activation, or module count difference. Lower current = shading, soiling, or high-resistance connection. Physical inspection identifies the cause.

questions.question: Monitoring shows one microinverter is offline. The first troubleshooting step is:

options.text: Check AC trunk cable connection and DC connection from module

questions.explanation: Single micro offline could be: disconnected trunk cable, loose DC connection from module, failed microinverter, or communication issue. Check connections first—most 'failures' are connection issues. Reset/power cycle if connections are good.

questions.question: Multiple microinverters on one branch show offline. This suggests:

options.text: Branch circuit breaker tripped or trunk cable issue

questions.explanation: Multiple offline micros on one branch indicate a common cause: tripped branch breaker, damaged trunk cable, or disconnected cable segment. Check the branch breaker first, then inspect the trunk cable from the affected section back to the junction box.

questions.question: One DC optimizer shows zero output while others produce normally. Check:

options.text: DC input from module, optimizer connections, and the optimizer itself

questions.explanation: Single optimizer offline could be: disconnected DC input from module, failed optimizer, or damaged connection. Check module output Voc directly (bypass the optimizer), check optimizer connections. Replace optimizer if inputs are good but no output.

questions.question: Monitoring system shows no data despite inverter operating and producing power. Check:

options.text: Internet connection, communication settings, and monitoring gateway

questions.explanation: Production without monitoring data indicates communication failure, not production failure. Check internet connectivity, WiFi/Ethernet connections to inverter or gateway, router firewall settings, and monitoring portal configuration.

questions.question: System has repeated ground fault trips that clear when reset but recur. Possible cause:

options.text: Intermittent fault from moisture, damaged insulation, or wildlife

questions.explanation: Intermittent ground faults often correlate with conditions: morning dew, rain, or temperature. Moisture in compromised insulation or junction boxes causes temporary faults. Inspect for damage, cracked conduit, unsealed penetrations, or rodent damage.

questions.question: To locate an intermittent ground fault, an effective approach is:

options.text: Systematic isolation testing of each string/segment with megger during fault conditions

questions.explanation: Test during conditions that trigger the fault (wet weather, morning). Disconnect strings and test each with megger. Isolate segments (combiner to inverter, junction box to combiner) to narrow location. Low insulation resistance indicates the affected section.

questions.question: Rapid shutdown doesn't function when tested. First check:

options.text: Control wiring, communication link, and equipment power

questions.explanation: Rapid shutdown systems require proper control wiring/communication between the initiation device (disconnect) and the shutdown equipment (MLPE, separate controllers). Check control conductors, power supply to shutdown equipment, and equipment configuration.

questions.question: After rapid shutdown initiation, array voltage should reduce to 80V or less within:
questions.explanation: Per NEC 690.12(B)(2), PV conductors within the array boundary must reduce to 80V or less within 30 seconds of rapid shutdown initiation. Conductors outside the array boundary must reduce to 30V within the same time. Test with voltmeter during commissioning.

questions.question: Battery system shows 'communication error' with inverter. Check:

options.text: Data cables between battery BMS and inverter

questions.explanation: Battery communication errors indicate problems with the data link between battery management system (BMS) and inverter. Check communication cables (often CAN bus or RS485), connections, and proper termination. Verify settings match equipment.

questions.question: Battery capacity has declined significantly over 2 years. Possible causes include:

options.text: Calendar aging, excessive cycling, temperature extremes, or deep discharge

questions.explanation: Battery capacity naturally decreases with age and use. Accelerated degradation results from: frequent deep discharge, operation at temperature extremes (too hot or cold), high cycle count, or manufacturing defects. Compare to warranty degradation limits.

questions.question: Battery system won't provide backup during outage despite being charged. Check:

options.text: Backup mode settings, transfer switch operation, and critical loads panel

questions.explanation: Verify: backup mode is enabled in inverter settings, transfer switch/contactor operates correctly to isolate from grid, critical loads panel is properly connected, and battery has sufficient charge. Test backup function intentionally during commissioning.

questions.question: After a windstorm, one module is askew on the roof. Check for:

options.text: Loose clamps, bent rails, or failed roof attachments

questions.explanation: Displaced modules indicate mechanical failure. Inspect: module clamps (loose, broken), rails (bent, disconnected), and roof attachments (pulled out, failed). Check adjacent modules and entire array for hidden damage. Re-secure before energizing.

questions.question: Roof shows water staining below a PV attachment point. The issue is likely:

options.text: Failed flashing or sealant at the penetration

questions.explanation: Water staining below attachment points indicates failed waterproofing. Inspect flashing condition (lifted, damaged), sealant integrity (cracked, missing), and proper integration with roofing. Repair the penetration to prevent structural damage.

questions.question: Evidence of rodent activity under the array (nesting, chewed cables). Action required:

options.text: Remove nesting, inspect for wire damage, install critter guard

questions.explanation: Rodents chew wire insulation causing ground faults, arc faults, and fires. Remove all nesting material, thoroughly inspect all wiring for damage, repair/replace damaged cables, and install critter guards to prevent future access.

questions.question: After a lightning storm, the inverter is completely dead with burn marks. This indicates:

options.text: Lightning strike or surge damage requiring complete inspection

questions.explanation: Lightning surges can damage or destroy inverters even without direct strikes. Inspect all equipment for damage: inverter, disconnect, combiner, MLPE, and monitoring. Check surge protectors (if installed). Document for insurance claim before repairs.

questions.question: System performance ratio (PR) has dropped from 0.85 to 0.70 over one year. Investigation should focus on:

options.text: All possible loss factors: shading, soiling, equipment, connections

questions.explanation: PR drop of 15 percentage points far exceeds normal degradation (<1%/year). Systematically check: new shading, soiling, equipment faults, string issues, inverter performance, and monitoring accuracy. This magnitude indicates real problems.

questions.question: A 10 kW system should produce approximately 40 kWh on a 5 peak-sun-hour day with 80% PR. Actual production is 28 kWh. The system is producing:
questions.explanation: Expected: 10 kW × 5 hours × 0.80 = 40 kWh. Actual: 28 kWh = 70% of expected, or 30% underproduction. This significant shortfall requires troubleshooting. Compare multiple days to rule out weather, then investigate equipment.

questions.question: Before filing a module warranty claim for underperformance, document:

options.text: Serial number, installation date, test data, and photos of defects

questions.explanation: Warranty claims require documentation: module serial number, installation date, operating conditions, test results (IV curve, Voc, Isc), photos of visible defects (hot spots, discoloration), and comparison to expected performance. Follow manufacturer's claim process.

questions.question: When comparing a system's production to a nearby reference system, differences could be explained by:

options.text: Orientation, tilt, shading, equipment type, and system size differences

questions.explanation: Valid comparison requires similar: orientation (azimuth), tilt angle, shading conditions, equipment efficiency, and normalized production (kWh/kW). Even nearby systems can have significantly different expected production based on these factors.

questions.question: String fuse is blown. Before replacing, check:

options.text: For short circuit, ground fault, or overcurrent cause in the string

questions.explanation: Blown fuses indicate overcurrent from short circuits, ground faults, or reverse current from other strings. Investigate before replacing—a new fuse will just blow again if the fault isn't corrected. Measure string insulation and check for damaged wiring.

questions.question: Measuring continuity between positive and negative conductors of an isolated string shows very low resistance. This indicates:
questions.explanation: Low resistance between positive and negative suggests a short circuit—conductors are touching or connected through a low-resistance path. Locate by isolating modules until resistance returns to normal. Often from damaged insulation or connector failure.

questions.question: Voltage measured across a connector shows a drop of 5V under load. This indicates:
questions.explanation: Voltage drop across connectors should be negligible (<0.5V). A 5V drop indicates high resistance, which wastes power and generates heat. Replace the connector—high resistance will worsen over time and may cause arc faults.

questions.question: The utility meter shows different production than the inverter display. This could be due to:

options.text: Meter and inverter should always match exactly
Line losses between inverter and meter, measurement accuracy, or metering method

questions.explanation: Differences are normal: line losses between inverter and meter, different measurement accuracy (inverter ~±2%, revenue meter ~±0.5%), and different measurement points. Net meter shows export only, not total production. Compare similar metrics.

questions.question: Inverter repeatedly disconnects at the same time each day. Possible cause:

options.text: Grid voltage or frequency excursion at that time from utility or local loads

questions.explanation: Time-correlated disconnections suggest external triggers: utility switching operations, large loads starting (industrial equipment), or voltage fluctuations from high PV penetration at solar noon. Monitor grid voltage during events. Contact utility if persistent.

questions.question: Inverter frequently shows 'High Grid Voltage' errors mid-day. The likely cause is:

options.text: Grid voltage rise from PV export, possibly undersized conductors

questions.explanation: Grid voltage rises when current flows 'backwards' to the grid. Causes: high PV export during peak production, undersized AC conductors (voltage drop in reverse), or stiff transformer. May require conductor upgrade, inverter settings adjustment, or utility coordination.

questions.question: System produces well in spring and fall but clipping occurs in summer. The likely cause is:

options.text: DC/AC ratio exceeds 1.0, normal clipping in high-irradiance conditions

questions.explanation: Clipping in summer peak indicates the DC array output exceeds inverter AC capacity during high-irradiance periods. This is normal with DC/AC ratios >1.0. Some clipping improves overall energy capture by boosting shoulder-hour production.

questions.question: System produces less in winter than modeling predicted. Possible causes include:

options.text: Snow coverage, shorter days, lower sun angle, or modeling inaccuracy

questions.explanation: Winter production shortfall can result from: snow coverage (even partial), more clouds than modeled TMY data, lower sun angles causing more shading, or reflective losses at low angles. Compare to models accounting for actual weather.

questions.question: After snowfall, production is zero despite sunny skies. The reason is:

options.text: Snow covering modules blocks all light to cells

questions.explanation: Even partial snow coverage severely reduces production. Complete coverage blocks all light—even if sunny above, cells receive no irradiance. Production resumes as snow melts or slides off. Steep tilts shed snow faster.

questions.question: A systematic troubleshooting approach includes documenting:

options.text: Symptoms, tests performed, results, and corrective actions taken

questions.explanation: Document: initial symptoms, date/conditions, tests performed and results, diagnosis, corrective actions, and verification of repair. This creates a maintenance history, supports warranty claims, identifies recurring issues, and helps future troubleshooting.

questions.question: Essential test equipment for PV troubleshooting includes:

options.text: DC multimeter, clamp meter, megger, and thermal camera

questions.explanation: Basic kit: DC multimeter (600V+ rating) for voltage, DC clamp meter for current, megohmmeter for insulation testing. Advanced: thermal camera for hot spots, IV curve tracer for detailed analysis. All equipment should be properly rated and calibrated.

questions.question: Before using a multimeter on a PV system, verify:

options.text: Meter is rated for expected voltage/current, CAT rating, and calibration

questions.explanation: Verify: voltage rating exceeds maximum system voltage, current rating exceeds maximum circuit current, appropriate CAT rating for installation location (CAT III for distribution), and calibration is current. Using inadequate meters is hazardous.

questions.question: The 'half-string' troubleshooting method involves:

options.text: Systematically isolating half the modules at a time to locate faults

questions.explanation: Binary search for faults: disconnect the string midpoint. Test each half. The faulty half shows the problem. Subdivide that half again. Repeat until the faulty module or segment is isolated. Efficient for long strings.

questions.question: Electroluminescence (EL) imaging is used to detect:

options.text: Micro-cracks, dead cells, and defects not visible externally

questions.explanation: EL imaging applies current to modules (reverse of normal operation) causing cells to emit light. Camera captures the image showing inactive areas (cracks, dead cells, poor contacts) as dark spots. Requires dark conditions and specialized equipment.

questions.question: An inverter shows intermittent 'low insulation' faults only on foggy mornings. This is likely caused by:

options.text: Moisture/condensation on surfaces temporarily reducing insulation resistance

questions.explanation: Morning condensation can temporarily reduce insulation resistance below threshold, triggering faults that clear as surfaces dry. If consistent with weather patterns and no permanent faults are found, this may be normal. Severe or persistent faults require investigation.

questions.question: After an inverter firmware update, the system behaves differently. The first step is:

options.text: Review update notes, verify settings, and monitor for issues

questions.explanation: Firmware updates can change settings or behavior. Review release notes for changes, verify critical settings (grid parameters, MPPT settings) remain correct, and monitor system for any issues. Contact manufacturer support if problems persist.

questions.question: Before making a site visit for underperformance, remote diagnostics should include:

options.text: Reviewing monitoring data, error logs, weather data, and comparing to expected

questions.explanation: Remote analysis often identifies causes or narrows possibilities: review production vs. irradiance, check error codes/history, compare string performance, and verify communication status. This preparation makes site visits more efficient and may avoid unnecessary trips.

questions.question: A common troubleshooting mistake is:

options.text: Starting with the most likely cause
Replacing components without testing or diagnosis

questions.explanation: Replacing parts without diagnosis wastes time and money, may not fix the problem, and obscures the real cause. Always: gather information, form hypothesis, test to confirm, then replace the confirmed faulty component, and verify the repair.

questions.question: After completing a repair, the final step is:

options.text: Verify the repair resolved the issue and document the work

questions.explanation: Always verify: system produces expected output, error codes cleared, and normal operation confirmed. Monitor for a period if possible. Document the repair, update maintenance records, and inform the customer of what was done.

questions.question: Annual module degradation of 2% per year (vs. typical 0.5%) indicates:
questions.explanation: 2%/year degradation is 4× the typical rate and exceeds most warranty limits. Causes include: PID, LID, hot spots, delamination, or manufacturing defects. Document degradation with test data for warranty claims. Module replacement may be warranted.

questions.question: To accurately assess module degradation, compare current output to:

options.text: Original specifications corrected for actual irradiance and temperature

questions.explanation: Compare measured power to STC rating corrected for actual conditions: Power_measured ÷ (Irradiance/1000) ÷ (1 + TempCoef × (Tcell-25)). IV curve tracers automate this correction. Difference from nameplate indicates degradation or defects.

questions.question: A failed bypass diode can cause:

options.text: Hot spots, reduced output, or string failure depending on failure mode

questions.explanation: Bypass diode failures: short-circuit failure bypasses cells permanently (lost power but protects against hot spots); open-circuit failure allows hot spots under shading (fire risk). Test diodes with multimeter in diode mode or thermal imaging.

questions.question: To test bypass diodes, measure forward voltage drop with multimeter in diode mode. Normal reading is:
questions.explanation: Normal diodes show 0.3-0.7V forward drop (Schottky ~0.3V, silicon ~0.6V) and OL (open) in reverse. Shorted diodes show 0V in both directions. Open diodes show OL in both directions. Access diodes through junction box.

questions.question: Signs of junction box problems include:

options.text: Discoloration, melting, corrosion, or water staining

questions.explanation: Junction box issues show as: heat discoloration, melted plastic, corrosion from moisture ingress, water staining inside or around, failed potting compound, or loose/corroded terminals. These indicate connection problems requiring module replacement.

questions.question: Inverter MPPT is not tracking to maximum power (stays at low power point). Check for:

options.text: Partial shading causing multiple power peaks, or MPPT settings

questions.explanation: Partial shading creates multiple MPPs; inverter may track a local (lower) peak instead of global maximum. Advanced MPPT algorithms (global MPPT) help. Also check MPPT configuration settings for voltage/current limits that might constrain operation.

questions.question: Inverter efficiency has dropped from 96% to 88%. Possible causes:

options.text: Internal component degradation, thermal problems, or MPPT issues

questions.explanation: Inverter efficiency decline indicates internal issues: capacitor degradation, thermal management problems (fan failure, blocked vents), or control issues. 8% efficiency loss is significant—the inverter may need service or replacement.

questions.question: Monitoring shows small power consumption at night. This is likely:
questions.explanation: Inverters draw 1-10W at night for standby functions (monitoring, communication, grid sensing). This appears as small consumption on monitoring systems. It's normal unless significantly higher than manufacturer specs.

questions.question: Customer disputes that system isn't producing what was promised. First verify:

options.text: Actual production vs. design estimate under actual weather conditions

questions.explanation: Compare actual production (from monitoring) to design estimate. Account for actual vs. typical weather. Production guarantees typically compare to weather-normalized expectations, not fixed kWh values. If shortfall exists, investigate causes.

questions.question: Customer reports 'the solar isn't working because my electric bill increased.' First check:

options.text: Verify production is normal—bill increase may be consumption increase

questions.explanation: Verify production first—if normal, the issue is likely increased consumption (new loads, weather, occupancy changes) or rate changes. Compare production data to past periods and to expectations. Educate customer about PV production vs. consumption.

questions.question: Mixing MC4 connectors from different manufacturers often leads to:

options.text: Poor connections, water ingress, and premature failure

questions.explanation: Despite appearing compatible, different MC4 brands have slight dimensional differences that cause poor sealing and contact. This leads to high resistance, arcing, moisture ingress, and failures. Always use matched connector pairs from same manufacturer.

questions.question: Reversed polarity wiring at a combiner can cause:

options.text: Damage to inverter, blown fuses, or fire

questions.explanation: Reversed polarity creates a short circuit when strings connect, resulting in high current that can damage equipment, blow fuses, or cause fires. Always verify polarity before connecting strings to inverter or combiner.

questions.question: Nuisance arc-fault trips during rapid irradiance changes (cloud edges) can often be resolved by:

options.text: Firmware updates, sensitivity adjustments, or manufacturer consultation

questions.explanation: Some inverters have sensitive AFCI that triggers on normal conditions like cloud transients. Manufacturer may offer firmware updates or sensitivity adjustments. Don't disable protection—work with manufacturer to balance sensitivity and nuisance trips.

questions.question: System production drops to zero for random periods during sunny days, then resumes. Check:

options.text: Grid voltage, inverter errors, and loose connections

questions.explanation: Random production dropouts suggest: grid voltage excursions causing inverter disconnect, loose connections interrupting DC circuit, or intermittent inverter faults. Check error logs for timestamps, correlate with conditions, and inspect connections.

questions.question: Monitoring shows negative production values at night. This indicates:

options.text: CT sensor installed backwards or measuring consumption

questions.explanation: Negative readings typically mean the current transformer (CT) is installed backwards, measuring current flow in the wrong direction. Or the CT is on a consumption circuit rather than production. Verify CT orientation and placement per installation guide.

questions.question: Production data stops updating in monitoring app. First troubleshooting step:

options.text: Check internet connection and communication gateway

questions.explanation: Monitoring data loss is usually communication failure, not production failure. Check: internet connectivity, WiFi/Ethernet connections, gateway power, and cloud service status. Inverter may be producing normally but unable to report data.

questions.question: During visual inspection, which is NOT a sign of potential problems?

options.text: Clean, intact modules with secure mounting

questions.explanation: Visual inspection looks for problems: discoloration (heat damage), loose components, damaged cables, pest activity, soiling, shading obstructions. Clean modules, intact frames, secure mounting, and proper cable management are normal/good conditions.

questions.question: A commissioning baseline helps troubleshooting by providing:

options.text: Original measurements to compare against current performance

questions.explanation: Commissioning data (string Voc, Isc, insulation resistance, IV curves) establishes normal baseline. Comparing current measurements to baseline reveals degradation or changes. Without baseline, detecting subtle problems is difficult.

questions.question: True root cause analysis for a PV system failure investigates:

options.text: Why the failure occurred to prevent recurrence

questions.explanation: Root cause analysis goes beyond 'what failed' to 'why it failed.' A burned connector's root cause might be: improper crimping, mismatched brands, or installation in high-temperature location. Addressing root cause prevents repeat failures.

questions.question: When should manufacturer technical support be contacted?

options.text: When troubleshooting exceeds installer capability or for complex/recurring issues

questions.explanation: Contact manufacturer support for: complex error codes, recurring issues after standard troubleshooting, firmware questions, warranty claims, and unusual behaviors. Have model number, serial number, and error details ready. Document their recommendations.

questions.question: When deciding between repairing and replacing a 10-year-old inverter, consider:

options.text: Repair cost vs. replacement cost, remaining warranty, efficiency improvements

questions.explanation: Consider total economics: repair cost, remaining useful life post-repair, warranty status, efficiency of old vs. new models (newer may be 2-3% more efficient), and potential for additional failures. Sometimes replacement is more cost-effective.

questions.question: Regular preventive maintenance for PV systems should include:

options.text: Visual inspection, cleaning, connection checks, and performance verification

questions.explanation: PM includes: visual inspection of all components, module cleaning as needed, checking connection tightness, reviewing production data, verifying grounding continuity, and testing safety systems. Frequency depends on environment and system size.

questions.question: Typical recommended maintenance inspection interval for residential PV is:
questions.explanation: Annual inspections are typical for residential, more frequent for commercial. Check manufacturer recommendations. Environmental factors (dust, salt air, wildlife) may require more frequent attention. Monitoring reduces need for frequent site visits.

questions.question: When multiple issues are found during inspection, prioritize by:

options.text: Safety first, then production impact, then cosmetic

questions.explanation: Prioritize: safety issues first (fire hazards, shock hazards, structural risks), then production-impacting issues (failed equipment, shading), then minor issues (soiling, cosmetic damage). Document all issues even if not immediately addressed.

questions.question: After replacing a module, verify the repair by:

options.text: Measuring string Voc, comparing to other strings, and monitoring production

questions.explanation: Verify replacement: measure string Voc (should match other strings), check connections, verify production on monitoring after energizing. A failed 'new' module or connection error would be caught before leaving the site.

questions.question: When replacing a module with a different model, ensure:

options.text: Electrical parameters (Vmp, Imp) are compatible with string and inverter

questions.explanation: Replacement modules should have similar Vmp and Imp to maintain string compatibility. Higher Vmp could push string voltage over inverter limit; mismatched Imp causes mismatch losses. Check that string stays within inverter MPPT window.

questions.question: When replacing an inverter with a different model, verify:

options.text: Voltage/current ratings, MPPT compatibility, and interconnection compliance

questions.explanation: New inverter must: handle string voltage range (Voc max, MPPT min/max), accept array current, provide required AC output, comply with utility interconnection requirements (UL 1741 listing, settings), and meet rapid shutdown needs.

questions.question: Upon discovering a fire hazard (melted components, burning smell), immediately:

options.text: Continue troubleshooting to find root cause
De-energize system, cover array if safe, and call fire department if needed

questions.explanation: Fire hazards require immediate response: de-energize by opening all disconnects, cover the array with opaque material if safely accessible, evacuate, and call fire department if fire is present or suspected. Document after the emergency is controlled.

questions.question: If a fire is discovered in a PV system, first responders should know:

options.text: PV arrays produce power in light even when disconnected
Turning off the inverter stops all power

questions.explanation: First responders must understand: PV arrays produce DC power whenever exposed to light—they can't be completely de-energized during daylight. Rapid shutdown reduces but may not eliminate voltage. Treat DC conductors as energized.

questions.question: After resolving a significant system failure, best practice includes:

options.text: Documenting the failure, cause, solution, and preventive measures

questions.explanation: Document lessons learned: what failed, why, how it was diagnosed, what fixed it, and what could prevent recurrence. This builds knowledge base, improves future installations, and helps train other technicians on real-world issues.
